displayed_text: Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: You want us to print it? Patient: Seven to twenty nine. Doctor: Yeah, it is, it is a mess. Patient: I haven't read it before. Doctor: I mean, most of it is, um, I say usual, you might get tired, because tired is always tops of everything. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We always got to watch your blood counts, because we always got to watch your blood counts. And that means white cells, red cells, platelets, and then of course, liver and kidney numbers. But that's blood tests. So you don't necessarily feel bad from that. We do know that some patients, their platelets go down a little bit. And that in some other patients, you might get a little bit of stomach upset. So not like full blown oh my gosh, you can't eat anything. And if that is the case, then we would have to, you know, modify the medication dose. But you can get a slight, you know, nausea or upset stomach. So we'd have to figure out how that plays with you. Other than that, that’s about it, so it's basically another hormone pill. So Xtandi, tackles one pathway of the receptor. This pill is another pathway. They are somewhat related, but this is not a chemo, it's actually another hormone. Yeah. So we're just trying to make sure you're super castrated, and then some, and then some. Patient: There’s that euphemism for the Prius. Patient: So, how does it affect my heart? Doctor: So obviously, we have to make sure that we take care of it, it shouldn't affect there's no direct effect, you know, it's not like, here's the chemo and Oh, boy. The Xtandi is, you know, always has a potential for heart issues, because we can't say that it doesn't, because anything that touches that testosterone pathway puts you in more of a menopause and accelerates heart disease. But that's true with your, you know, Lupron, that's true for all the other pills you've been on. Unfortunately, that's the main sort of active drug with all of this with prostate cancer. So that's the tough part. This one shouldn't have a cardiac thing. But again, this is a study. So if you do have a worsening cardiac thing that's reportable, because we would want to make sure that no other person has that. Patient: So they don't know that? Doctor: Oh, no, this is why it's a study. I mean, this is- you’re guinea pig, once again, you know, like you tell us what's going on. But it isn't like this is a chemo or something that we're really worried that this might worsen heart disease. But it's always this- every time you fool around with the hormone receptors, you know, it can worsen heart disease in general. So I don't know about this particular combo, but that's why it's on a study and not me just go in here, take this.

Patient: I need my OxyContin. Doctor: Yeah the OxyContin you’re gonna get no matter what. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That you keep going. Patient: Okay. Take Percocet… Doctor: Instead of the Norco. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Right. Healthcare Professional: Alright. Doctor: So let’s do that, see how you do and then we’ll switch, we’ll add the sleeping pill. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Aside from the fact, do we have an appointment time for September fifth? Only because I just need to know so that if I need to adjust my schedule at school, um, so. Healthcare Professional: So, September fifth, nine-thirty lab work, and ten-thirty, the visit. So the time is nine-thirty to ten-thirty. Family Member: Now, for the next, I guess, will be continue to have doctor at ten-thirty? Doctor: Not necessarily. If you wants them at K___, who’s there that day, what the schedule looks like. Do you prefer later or earlier? Family Member: Mm, I mean. Doctor: Yeah. L___ can help with scheduling. If you prefer, like an afternoon appointment, let’s say, instead of morning, or if you want to be like the very first patient that comes in. The lab I think opens at six a.m. So we have some patients that come like at six and then see that doctor. Most people don’t want to come that early. Patient: And, and I want you to know that I, I thought this discussion was going to be today. Doctor: I’m glad I met your expectations. Patient: Yeah. I thought this was going to come up, and I said, okay. But it is what it is. Healthcare Professional: I will communicate with L___, and she’ll contact you probably tomorrow, about she will get in contact with K. She will set everything up for you. Patient: Okay. Thank you. Doctor, it’s always good to see you. And thank you for your advice. And we’re going to follow your lead. Doctor: And I’ll follow your lead. We’ll help each other.

Patient: Yeah I Doctor: Where were you now? Patient: I was down in Kentucky. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Mhmm. Sometimes I have to travel for the job. Doctor: That’s good. Was it hot? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Right now it must be boiling down there. Michigan is pleasant. Patient: Yeah compared to Kentucky, yes. Doctor: So next week I’m thinking if we get you authorized for this Firmagon injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay I can always cancel if I don’t need it.

Healthcare Professional: And if he feels like he’s having side effects or just doesn’t want to do it anymore or participate, just let me know. Doctor: Same thing. I would manage the side effects whether you’re on the study or not. Family Member: Right. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Whether you’re on the study or not, you have a problem at one a.m. on a Saturday, you still page me. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Same. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we appreciate… Healthcare Professional: But you can always call me too… (laughs) Doctor: Yeah. (Laughter)

Family Member: Not the sixteenth? Doctor: I’ll e-mail him, but you can also tell him at the next appointment. Patient: I will. Doctor: You think it’s best – does he think it’s a good idea? He and I do this all the time. We, we transition after he’s finished with the radiation part. Because, unless - I mean, he’s not going away. We might need him again. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Down the road maybe. I don’t know. I hope not. But, but, but I think in terms of talking about the next trials, all those kinds of things, you need to be with, you’re going to, that’s going to be me. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Patient: I have a question. Yesterday, the dermatologist told me that there is a over-the-counter - uh, uh, medication, whatever, that, um, if taken twice day, it was just in the New England Journal of Medicine, reduces the chances of melanoma significantly. Family Member: Oh, the nicotimini, nicotiminey? Nicotinomi? Patient: Have you seen any of that? Doctor: I did not see that. No. Family Member: That’s not his thing, I don’t think.

Patient: Yeah. Since you took, you said that. Right, huh, huh, huh, right there. It feels like a, a scab. But then sometimes it feels like a, a needle. Doctor: But you can pinpoint it to the one place? Patient: Yep. Doctor: That’s a little dry skin there. Okay. Patient: And then you scratch it- Doctor: Anything else to look at? Any swelling or anything? Patient: No. Doctor: It looks, I know it’s got a little scab to it. Patient: Well, that’s because I take my fingernail and I scratch it. And the only reason I scratch it is because when your shirt hits it, it hurts. You told me to mention everything. Are these cameras on? Doctor: They are. Patient: With me, me running off at the jaws. Doctor: Today, your white count is fine. Your anemia is unchanged. So that’s normal when you’re on these medicines a lower testosterone. Your platelets are also normal. Kidney function looks good. Your albumin is better. Your alkaline phosphatase is the same. Everything else is normal.

Family Member: Yeah. Thank you Jesus. Doctor: Um hmm. Family Member: But um he was asking me did he ever have an MRI of the prostate lymph nodes. Doctor: Prostate – no, I don’t think so. Family Member: No. Doctor: He had a CAT scan. Family Member: Yeah. Now will that show if there was any problem or would it? Doctor: Well – Family Member: I know MRI show more. Doctor: Well they both can show that. I think it’s more of what are we looking for to do with that. Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: He’s sort of past that.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, I I did want to speak to you about um a research study that we’re doing that I think would be a good fit for you and I wanted to give you some details about that. Patient: Mm-kay. Doctor: And then give you some time to uh look at some written information that I’ll give you to take home. And you can look at that with your sister and your great-niece and the three of you can decide together whether you think this might be good idea for you. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And um I just wanted to um write some notes down. And then after I write these notes, I’m going to give you some detailed information about the the clinical trials. So, if if you are not at J_____ H_____. If you were just seeing a medical oncologist without- private practice or community um then the next step for someone like you, where the cancer might be growing or progressing despite the Abiraterone- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But typically we want to have two options. Number one would be switching from that pill to a different pill. And the second pill is called Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That is also known as Enzalutamide. Got a long name. The short name is Xtandi, the long name is Enzalutamide. And this is a pill you take it every day and it’s also four pills at a time. Four pills all at once. The dose is one hundred sixty milligrams. So it’s a little bit different from the Abiraterone. And this one does not require Prednisone, no Prednisone for this one. So it’s one less thing to take. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: The second option for some patients, whose cancer is progressing more rapidly, especially in those that its causing symptoms, like bone pain for example.

Patient: That’s what I do. Doctor: I know. Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: Gee, you and every other guy I have in my practice which is why I say this. Patient: Oh, Okay. Doctor: Please just recognize that your quality of life will be so much better Patient: Okay. Doctor: if we can just contain it. Now, sometimes people just take it twice a day, kind of like before bed for sure so you sleep well Patient: Right. Doctor: and then when you’re kind of up and running whether it’s after breakfast and you’re like I’m gonna get as much stuff as I can done and I’m just gonna relax and wait for my next dose. Some of my guys have to take it three times a day and some of my guys are just like I’m okay, I can stand this stuff, it’s doable but at night I just can’t sleep. It’s just there all the time the achiness and pain. Patient: Right. Doctor: and they take it at night. However you do it just know it will constipate you. Patient: I know that, yes.

Family Member: We’re being nice to them and saying here, look at this. & DOC Laughing]] Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay so first of all let me go ask Dr. L____ if he can see you today. Patient: Okay, oh yeah? That would be nice. Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Let me go check with him. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And meanwhile as I get all the scans and all that and get a chance to look at your bone scans. Patient: Do you want me to step out or stay here? Doctor: Uh stay here. If Dr. L____ wants you moved to a different room of his I’ll let you know. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Patient: Sounds good. Thank you. Doctor: Okay and today your Lupron and all that you’ve been getting right with Dr. K____. Okay so that’s updated.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: ‘Cuz – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Don’t – Patient: And I can just – Doctor: Don’t aggravate! Patient: Tell the difference. I can tell the difference. Doctor: Oh, yeah. And we know you’re okay now ‘cuz we know when you’re not okay because it’s not subtle. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: When you’re not okay, you’re just being – peeing gobs of blood, tissue – we know you’re not okay. That’s not happening right now. So, we’re at this perfect window – Patient: Right. Doctor: Where we gotta make a decision – Patient: So okay, doc. So, let me --

Patient: Okay. And that was the same thing with the magnesium. Right? Doctor: Correct Patient: Because you advised no magnesium? Doctor: Well, no. A normal level of magnesium is good. Patient: A normal level Family Member: Like in a multivitamin magnesium? Doctor: Correct. Yes. Family Member: If you could maybe have somebody Google or you Google fluorescence and just see what it’s got that wild Doctor: Okay. Patient: Flor-essence. Doctor: Okay. Flor-essence. Done. Nice to see you. Hello. Hello. Hello. And Good-bye. Do you have enough to eat and drink? Feeling better? Patient: So. Yeah. Oh. I wanted to go to Hospital DR. How do I get to Hospital DR from here? How do I get to DR from here? Can I get a navigator? Doctor: Oh. Yeah a navigator. I couldn’t explain it if my life depended on it, and I’ve been here fourteen years.

Patient: Okay but what I do in the meantime (laughs) Doctor: Well that’s why I was saying that well if there was somebody else with you, I’m concerned that you’re going to take both and it will be too much, it will zonk you out. Okay there’s nobody here with you even to tell for me to tell and the dangerous thing is you have your Ambiens at home. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you very well could make a mistake and take both, take the Ambien and the new sleeping pill. Patient: No I wouldn’t take the Ambien then. I’ll just throw them out. Doctor: You sure? Patient: Yeah I will pull them out. Doctor: You’ll remember to do that?
PAT Yes, yes I will. Okay. Patient: Yes I will. I would so like it now I would take them Ambiens that I got, I will pull them out. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yeah I’ll dispose, how do we say it, dispose of them. Doctor: Now you’re gonna remember to do that? Patient: Yes I am, yes I am.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The reason is so you know everybody wants to be helpful and you know give you all kinds of natural products and things like mistletoe or kabuki mushrooms or whatever. The problem is that a lot of them are antioxidants. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So they’re really good stuff, except when you’re trying to kill bad things, and then they interfere because one of the things we’re trying to do in chemo is make reactive oxygen species which kill, make the DNA not work and breaks up and then the cells break up. If you give a medicine like mistletoe to interfere with the creation of those uh you know, what’s basically hydrogen peroxide that kills ah the cells, then you’re interfering with chemotherapy and radiation therapies. Family Member: The effectiveness of the chemo Patient: So that would be something . Uh nutrition – Then I’m scheduled to speak with someone from a company out of Colorado called Doctor: Hmmmm Patient: Should I hold off on that during the period of treatment as well? Doctor: So, so, yes. Uhm um they have some things that interfere with what we do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so I’m you know all holistic approaches for all these things. I can tell you back in the day I wrote books about this stuff. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian
